subject: Re: How to test private member variables?
msgSnippet: ... like ... two ... () ... line ... expectations ... builder. This tests that the builder calls the interface s sets correctly. ... outside world doesn t need
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> >So said Dave Astels on 2003-07-24 --------------------
> >--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> >
> >JB's right on the money. Factor the command line parsing into it's
> >own class. Then it's encapsulated and can be cleanly refactored in
> >isolation.
> >
> >> Once you've done this, main() calls the parser, then does stuff
like
> >this:
> >>
> >> new MyClass(
> >> (Integer) args.get("blah"),
> >> (String) args.get("foo"),
> >> ...
> >> );
> >>
> >> A little ugly, due to the casting, but not horrible.
> >
> >Yes.. the joys of a straight-jacket language.
> >
> >Face it, it's hard to write Java, C++, C#, etc that isn't ugly.
> >
> >> 2. That main() passes the parameters correctly to MyClass'
> >> constructor?
> >>
> >> Rather than expose getX() methods, add equals() that compares
two
> >> MyClass objects and answers true if their fields have the same
> >> values. Then in your test, set up the "expected MyClass" with the
> >> argument values you expect main() to pass in and use assertEquals
()
> >> to compare them.
> >
> >Another option would be to pass a clean instance to the command
line
> >parser, which then acts as a builder.. calling setters on the
> >instance. Then you can pass in a mock to be built.. with
expectations
> >as to *how* it will be built.
>
> Hello! Ding ding ding.... that's nice.
>
> 1. Put the sets on an interface.
>
> 2. Expose get/set on Test Implementation and submit it to the
builder. This tests that the builder calls the interface's sets
correctly.
>
> 3. Don't expose get on Production Implementation because the
outside world doesn't need them.
>
> I like it.
>
>

Sorry I have some difficult to understand your great suggestions due
to my new to Junit. So far, I know that I need separate the command
line parsing into two steps. First is to transfer command line args
to a builder. Second is to use the builder to set the private member
variables. I could understand the first step to use equivalent
operation to compare two builder class objects. However, I have some
sort of difficult to understand the Second step. Could you provide
some code snippets to give more concrete explanations? Thanks very
much!
